Triggering Event: At 7 AM, she found a half-eaten breakfast left on the counter, milky cereal seeping into the pristine marble. Her partner had rushed off again without cleaning up, as if their shared home was his personal hospital ward. She felt hatred boil within her, imagining the mess left at work yesterday when he'd insisted on "helping." She slammed the dish into the sink, shards flying like shattered patience.
Generated Assessment: She stormed out of the kitchen, slamming the door behind her, her anger boiling over at the thought that this could be how every morning unfolded. Every day, he'd leave the house early, leaving her to clean up after him, and now it seemed he'd done it again, leaving her with a mountain of dishes. The fact that he didn't even bother washing them, just leaving them there for her to deal with, was infuriating. Why couldn't he see how much effort she put into keeping the apartment tidy? Why did he always have to rush off, never stopping to help? Her mind began to spin with thoughts of all the times he'd left her to deal with the mess, how he'd taken credit for her hard work while rushing back to his job. It wasn't fair. He knew how much she worked to keep everything organized and clean, but he never made an effort to return the favor. Even when she'd tried to explain that she needed some time to herself in the mornings, he wouldn't listen, just grabbing his bag and leaving. This was exactly why she hated mornings - because of him. As she walked down the stairs, she noticed the clock ticking away, and she realized she'd wasted too much time already. How could she possibly start her shift feeling this way? But why should she feel anything else? Shouldn't she be furious about being treated like this? After all, he was the one who got to go to work whenever he wanted

Triggering Event: In the staff room, she finds a crumpled note from yesterday's lesson in the trash. It's her carefully written teaching plan, now scribbled over with profanities and crude drawings. Her hands shake as she fishes it out, rage boiling within her. She can hear their laughter echoing down the hall.
Generated Assessment: You know how I'm always predicting doom and gloom? Well, this is exactly what I predicted would happen. I told myself that if you didn't have your shit together, you'd end up like this. You're supposed to be teaching, but instead, you're just fuming because someone threw away your precious lesson plan. You know what they say: "They who live by the sword die by the sword." And let me tell you, you're definitely living by the sword. The way you're acting right now, it's like you're trying to cut yourself loose from all the stress and anxiety you've been carrying around. But deep down, you know you're just going to build up even more tension until it explodes. It's pretty clear that you need to get your head back on straight. Maybe if you took some time to calm down before coming back into class, things wouldn't be so tense. But then again, maybe you're just too far gone for that. Either way, here's my prediction: you'll probably end up losing control completely today, and when you do, we'll all see how much damage you've done. ---

Triggering Event: In his studio, he found an unopened bottle of her favorite wine, tucked away behind some canvases. He'd forgotten about it until now. The sight of it sent a wave of despair crashing through him, as if her absence was palpable in that very moment.

It hit me like a ton of bricks when I realized I hadn't seen her smile in what felt like an eternity. Her presence had always brightened up the room, making everything seem more vibrant and alive. Now, every time I step into this studio, I'm reminded of all those moments we shared together. Sometimes, it feels like I'm just going through the motions, pretending to be okay when deep down, I’m struggling to come to terms with our separation. I must admit, there have been times when I’ve felt lost, unable to shake off the feeling of emptiness that followed her departure. Perhaps it’s because seeing the world through another’s eyes helps me appreciate its complexities, reminding me that even in sorrow, there is always something to cherish. Triggering Event: A middle-aged male doctor, widowed three years ago, feels his stomach churn as he enters the hospital's morgue to identify a deceased patient who had been his friend for decades. The sterile smell of disinfectant fails to mask the underlying scent of decay, triggering a wave of revulsion that threatens to overwhelm him.
Generated Assessment: I just can't even... I'm so sick of all this shit. Every time I come here, it reminds me of my wife. She was always so happy here; she loved coming back to her old workplace, reminiscing with the staff, and catching up with everyone. But now every time I walk in, I feel like I'm going to throw up. It's hard to breathe when you're standing there, staring at someone who used to be your best friend. You keep thinking about what they were doing right before they passed away, and how much pain they must have endured in those final moments. And then you think about all the little things you'll miss - the way she'd smile at you, the sound of her laughter, the way she'd always make everything okay. But all these memories come flooding back, making me feel like I'm drowning in grief. I can't help but wonder if I could've done something differently, if maybe if I'd been more supportive, if I'd been there enough for her, if I'd listened more closely, if I'd held her tighter, if I'd known sooner... And yet, despite all this, I still feel so guilty. I know she wouldn't want me to be like this, to let her death define me. But every time I try to shake off these feelings, they come back stronger. Triggering Event: He noticed the unsigned canvas leaning against the wall, his partner's paint still wet. His own brushes lay untouched for days. He felt a surge of heat in his chest, his hands clenching into fists. "This is my studio," he thought, his voice echoing in his mind like thunder.

Triggering Event: "While scrolling through work emails after dinner, he noticed one from his boss sent at 9:30 PM, subject line 'Urgent: Project Update'. He felt a knot form in his stomach as he worried about what tomorrow might bring."
Generated Assessment: His inbox is flooded with updates on projects he's no longer leading. The constant reminders of deadlines and expectations weigh heavily on him. It feels like every time he tries to relax, an email pops up demanding his attention. His mind is constantly racing with worries about how these tasks will impact his workload and stress levels.

Triggering Event:
Scenario:
Female nurse, aged 35 and married, arrives home from a twelve-hour shift to find her spouse has used the last of the milk for their coffee without replacing it. She had been looking forward to a cup of tea before bed.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I am so upset that he did this. He is always making me feel like shit when he does things like this. This time was no exception. It's just another example of how he never listens to me and doesn't care about my feelings at all. He always chooses to do whatever he wants instead of what I want, and I'm tired of having to deal with it. He's always doing this kind of thing, and I'm exhausted from dealing with it. Now I'll be up all night worrying about him being late again tomorrow because he won't stop leaving his dirty socks on the floor. I hate living with him. He always ignores my needs, and now I have to spend the entire day waiting for him to get home so I can talk to him about it.

"That's ridiculous. She's just trying to freak us out. We can't let her get inside our heads like that. Let's ignore everything she says and focus on what really matters – taking care of ourselves." Triggering Event: He glances at his reflection in the hospital's polished floor, seeing the grey stubble and deep lines etched into his face. His eyes flicker to the clock, then to the empty bed beside him. He had meant to visit her today, but duty called. Again.
Generated Assessment: He looks tired. There are fine lines around his eyes. The gray stubble makes him look older than he is. He has a lot of work ahead of him. He didn't have time for this visit. It would be better if she came here instead. She needs more care. I can't afford it myself right now.
